awd_titl_txt: NRT-DESE LUCID: A project-focused cross-disciplinary graduate training program for data-enabled research in human and machine learning and teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
NRT DESE: Learning, understanding, cognition, intelligence, and data science (LUCID)

In modern life there are many situations requiring people to interact with computers, either so that they may learn from the machine or so that the machine may learn from them. The applications in education, industry, health, robotics, and national security hint at the enormous societal and economic benefits arising from research into the technologies that promote learning in both people and computers. Yet the potential has been difficult to realize because such research requires scientists with expertise in quite different fields of study. While computer scientists receive training in complex computational ideas and methods, they know little about how people learn and behave. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award to the University of Wisconsin-Madison will prepare trainees with data-enabled science and engineering training to simultaneously understand computational theory and methods, the mechanisms that support human learning and behavior, and the ways these mechanisms behave in complex real-world situations. The traineeship anticipates equipping forty (40) doctoral students with the skills and expertise necessary to advance our understanding of human and machine learning and teaching, through a new training program that focuses on learning, understanding, cognition, intelligence, and data science.

This project will train doctoral students from computer science, engineering, cognitive psychology, and education sciences, with the goal of promoting a common knowledge base that allows these scientists to work productively across traditional boundaries on both basic research questions and practical, real-world problems. The traineeship will include several graduate training innovations: (1) a project-focused "prof-and-peer" mentoring system where scientists work in cross-disciplinary teams to address a shared research problem, (2) close involvement of partners in industry, government, and non-profit sectors to develop research problems with real-world application, (3) an information outreach effort that trains scientists to communicate with the public, industry, and policy-makers through traditional and new media outlets, (4) a flexible development plan that allows each trainee to garner the cross-disciplinary expertise needed to advance a particular research focus, and (5) new mechanisms for recruiting and retaining under-represented groups in STEM research. This training will prepare US scientists to compete globally at the highest levels for positions in science, industry, and government, in a growth sector of the 21st century knowledge economy. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative, and scalable models for STEM graduate education training.  The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through the comprehensive traineeship model that is innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

This award is supported, in part, by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, specifically the ECR Research in Disabilities Education (RDE) area of special interest.  ECR emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.  Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

por.por_cntn:
In modern life there are many situations requiring people to interact with computers, either so that they may learn from the machine or so that the machine may learn from them: in education, consider automatic tutoring systems and massively online course platforms; in industry, consider the many services that try to predict user preferences and serve recommendations; in human health, smart biometric technologies are helping people to manage their own care; in the public sphere, social networking technologies are allowing new modes of communication, persuasion, and mobilization. The potential benefits of these developments to society has been difficult to realize because progress requires scientists who simultaneously understand computational theory and methods, the mechanisms that support human learning and behavior, and the ways these mechanisms behave in complex real-world situations. This project developed a new inter-disciplinary graduate training program in which scientists from computational disciplines (computer science, engineering) collaborated with those in behavior disciplines (psychology, educational sciences) to tackle research problems at the intersection of computational and social sciences. Our goal was to develop a new cross-disciplinary science of learning, understanding, cognition, intelligence, and data science (LUCID). Over six years we enrolled 35 PhD-track candidates, organized them in small cross-disciplinary teams, and had them work together to generate new knowledge about human and machine learning.

 Intellectual merit. The LUCID program advanced basic and applied knowledge in several core research areas, including: (1) developing new tools for conducting online behavioral experiments, allowing partners in industry, government, and academia to make efficient use of crowd-sourced human-generated data; (2) combining cognitive theories of human learning with computer models to develop a new “machine teaching” framework that can help students learn to read, solve math problems, or acquire expertise in chemistry; (3) developing new models of human learning that help to explain why beliefs can be so resistant to change, and new computational techniques for preventing the spread of misinformation in social networks; (4) developing new technologies that allow robots to anticipate the actions of human partners, allowing humans and robots to work collaboratively; and (5) assessing new techniques for using social-media and other communications data to aid intervention, diagnosis, and treatment of addiction disorders and other mental illnesses. Additionally, this project pioneered and assessed new approaches to cross-disciplinary training that promoted extra-disciplinary learning and productivity without requiring extensive additional coursework.

Broader impact. The LUCID program created a new cross-disciplinary community at UW-Madison that now spans 9 Departments across behavioral and computational disciplines, with a strong focus on ways that data-science/AI and social sciences can interact to address some of society’s most pressing problems. The breadth of interest generated by the PhD program led to two additional, integrated programs, including a summer research program designed to provide talented undergraduates from under-represented groups with experience conducting data-infused behavioral science, and a new Professional Master’s degree in Data Science and Human Behavior. By combining social and computational sciences, we have increased the participation of women in computationally intensive STEM fields, and by pursuing research projects in collaboration with a wide array of partners, we have connected basic science to a variety of real-world applications. Our trainees have prepared for research careers in industry, government, and academia, laying the groundwork for a new infusion of computationally-informed social science into these sectors. Our graduates have found jobs in tenure-track, government research, and industrial positions.
